column11: The Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic in Kandy, Sri Lanka, is one of the most important Buddhist sites in the world. While several locations claim to house relics of the Buddha, this specific temple is widely recognized for enshrining his left upper canine tooth. The teachings of the Buddha were transmitted by word of mouth passing his canine tooth. The relic holds immense spiritual and political significance; historically, it was believed that whoever possessed the tooth had the right to govern the country. The temple attracts thousands of pilgrims and tourists daily. Its importance to Buddhists is often likened to that of Mecca or the Vatican. During major festivals like the Esala Perahera, when the relic's casket is brought out in a grand procession, the streets become densely packed with devotees and impassable for blocks.

The respective protector of the tooth was respected because he had religious support and his country could never be ravaged by drought. column11: On the lake, in the center of Kandy is the Sri Dalada Maligawa (Temple of the Tooth) built by King Sri Rajasinghe in 1807 and still the heart of the Sinhalese Buddhist religion. It actually has more ancient origins (late 1600s early 1700s) and was always thought to guard the sacred tooth of the Buddha, one of his canine teeth, which remained after cremation and was brought to safety here from India. Since ancient times, the sacred tooth has been paraded through the streets of Kandy on the back of an elephant during the Esala Perahera a huge festival that attracts pilgrims from all over. Attending the Esala Perahera, which lasts 10 days between late July and August on dates that vary depending on the full moon, can be a unique experience. The temple itself does not possess the same attractions as other temples in Sri Lanka or other Buddhist countries but the devotion of pilgrims is tangible. The sanctuary is two-story and the interior has parts in exotic woods, lacquer and ivory. The tooth is upstairs. You must wear clothes that cover your legs and shoulders and remove your shoes.

column11: Sri Dalada Maligawa is our favorite place to visit in Kandy. It is a very important place for Sri Lankan Buddhists. Sri Dalada Maligawa, also known as the Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic, is a Buddhist temple in Kandy, Sri Lanka. It is considered the most sacred place of Buddhist worship in Sri Lanka and perhaps the world, housing the relic of the tooth of the Buddha. The temple is located in the Royal Palace Complex of the former Kingdom of Kandy. The relic has played an important role in Sri Lankan politics since ancient times, as it is believed that whoever holds the relic holds the governance of the country. The relic was historically held by Sinhalese kings. The temple of the tooth is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. A must-see if you are a tourist, this place is revered by Sri Lankan pilgrims.

column11: When you hear the word ‚ÄúBuddha,‚Äù in the imagination of the ignorant, a statue of a man sitting in the ‚Äúlotus‚Äù position immediately appears with a body proportional like a Nyagrodha tree, with membranes between the fingers, with an ushnisha on the top of the head, a smile with forty teeth, etc. In reality, this same Buddha is not just an idol sculpted from one material or another. Siddhartha Gautama Shakyamuni (aka Gautama Buddha) is a key figure in Buddhism: he is a spiritual teacher and the founder of Buddhism, one of the three world religions. Alas, as with all such personalities, there is little reliable information about the biography of the Buddha: a number of Buddhist sutras (texts) in Pali and several Sanskrit scriptures: ‚ÄúBuddacharita‚Äù, ‚ÄúLalitavistara‚Äù and others. What is interesting is that when Buddha, at the age of 80, made the ‚ÄúGreat Transition into the Absolute Peace of Nirvana,‚Äù his body was cremated in accordance with the rite for the Universal Ruler. But then all sorts of Epic Fails begin on the topic of ‚Äúdividing the relics of the deceased.‚Äù If you believe the legends, the remains of the Buddha were divided into eight parts and lie at the base of specially erected stupas-suburgans - these are Buddhist architectural and sculptural religious structures of a hemispherical shape. So, when the relics of Buddha were being divided, someone cunning managed to steal the left fang of the deceased, which was taken to Ceylon. They say that Princess Hemamala and Prince Dantha from the city of Kalinga in India were involved in this action, and this happened during the reign of King Kirti Sri Meghavarna (sometime around 301-328 AD). In Ceylon, the TOOTH was declared a shrine and from that moment the history of the future Temple of the Sacred Relic of the Tooth Relic of Gautama Buddha, the Temple of the Tooth Relic, Sri Dalada Maligawa began!!! All these are names of the same religious building. And not just another Buddhist stupa, but one of the main and most revered shrines of the island!!! In Christianity, this question (I‚Äôm talking about sacred relics) is somehow more solid, or something: the Shroud of Turin, the Crown of Thorns, the Spear of Longinus, the Title INRI, the Holy Grail, nails (with which the body of Jesus was nailed to the Cross), and finally the pincers with which they took out those very nails... And then a TOOTH... A whole temple was built over it!!! The same existing Sri Dalada Maligawa in the city of Kandy, the capital of the Central Province of Sri Lanka. Like any shrine, from ancient times this TOOTH was attributed with a certain magical power - whoever owned the fang of the Buddha also had all the power. It is clear that under this ‚Äúsauce‚Äù the Buddha tooth became the property of the ruling Sri Lankan royal dynasty. The fate of the TOOTH was turbulent: it was always kept in the temple at the royal residence, and since the capital ‚Äúmoved‚Äù several times (Anuradapura, Pollonnaruwa, Dambadeniya, Yapahuwa, Kurunegala, Kotte Gampola), the TOOTH ‚Äútraveled‚Äù after it. Until he arrived in Kandy at the end of the 16th century. The first ‚ÄúDalada Madura‚Äù (or ‚ÄúDalada Mandira‚Äù, depending on how you write) to store the holy relic (I‚Äôm talking about the ZUB, of course) was built during the reign of King Vimaladharmasuriya I in 1592-1604. Alas, during the colonization of the island by the Portuguese, the temple was destroyed. The second sacral was erected on the same site during the reign of King Rajasinghe II from 1635 to 1687. Apparently, Temple of the Tooth was fatally unlucky - and this iconic building was burned, though now by the Dutch. In 1687, King Vimaladharmasuriya II built another Dalada Madura, and it had three floors!!! However, over time, the building fell into disrepair and was destroyed. And finally, his son, King Sri Vera Parakrama Narendrasinghe, who reigned from 1707 to 1739, built the current Dalada Maligawa, which, with minor architectural ‚Äúadjustments‚Äù by subsequent rulers, has survived to this day. The architecture of the sacral is executed in a unique Kandyan style in combination with details and elements of the style of ‚ÄúDalada Madura‚Äù - the forerunner sanctuaries, which previously housed the relic of the Sacred Tooth Relic of Buddha. The location chosen for the temple was simply magical: next to the ancient Royal Palace (the latter is located north of the temple) and a forest reserve called Udavatha Kelaya (to the east). The aura of this magnificent place is brightened by the famous Kandy Lake - the so-called Sea of Milk (also known as Bogambara and Kiri Mukhuda). I was probably lucky - there were practically no people (maybe it was just not the season), I refused the services of a guide - everything that interested me, I read on the internet the day before. I can‚Äôt say that I was deeply impressed by what I saw, but I recommend a visit to Sri Dalada Maligawa, if only because it is one of the most famous religious sites on the island.

column11: This sacred site, nestled within the heart of the Kandy city, is a testament to the rich history and religious significance of Sri Lanka. Upon entering the temple complex, the first thing that captures your attention is the magnificent architecture that seamlessly blends different traditional styles. The intricate carvings, vibrant paintings, and the imposing structure create an aura of grandeur, setting the stage for the profound experience that awaits inside. Main highlight of the temple is the sacred tooth relic of Lord Buddha enshrined within. The atmosphere inside the chamber is filled with a sense of reverence and devotion, as pilgrims and visitors alike gather to catch a glimpse of this revered relic. The temple complex also houses various other shrines, each adorned with unique religious artifacts and symbolic representations. Great surroundings with the picturesque Kandy Lake and the lush greenery. You will find knowledgeable guides there to provide insights into the temple's history and significance.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Also known as Sri Dalada Maligawa, the Tooth Relic Temple is an impressive place. It was given recognized as a UNESCO world heritage site in 1988. It is the main attraction in Kandy and definitely worth visiting. It‚Äôs located in the Royal Palace complex, with its white buildings and walls. It was bombed in 1989 & 1998 but is now fully restored. Don‚Äôt forget to take appropriate clothing to cover your knees and shoulders. I would definitely recommend getting one of the many guides to take you around as it is a huge place and can be quite confusing and also the information from the guides make it a much better experience. As it is one of the most important places of worship for Buddhists it is very busy. If visiting its best to check the opening times of the tooth relic room, the doors are closed at other times. There are plenty of impressive sights to see on the visit including the elephant memorial (Tusker Raja), a full sized taxidermy elephant of the most famous elephant that carried the tooth casket during the festival of the tooth in Kandy each year.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: The Temple of the Tooth in Kandy, Sri Lanka, holds immense cultural and religious significance as it enshrines a tooth believed to be that of Buddha. With opening hours from 5:30 am to 8:30 pm, visitors can immerse themselves in the temple's rich history and witness daily rituals, including puja ceremonies. Prayer time is 5.30am 6.30am 10.30am 6.30pm. Admission tickets, priced at approximately 2000 LKR, provide access to this UNESCO World Heritage Site. To respect local customs, it's advisable to dress modestly, ensuring shoulders and knees are covered. Before entering the temple, visitors are required to remove their shoes, a customary practice symbolizing reverence. The Temple of the Tooth offers a profound spiritual experience amid its historical splendor. A highly recommended destination for those visiting Kandy, the Temple of the Tooth offers a profound and culturally enriching experience, deeply rooted in reverence and historical significance.

We visited the elephant memorial (for Raja - the maligawa tusker) and didn‚Äôt feel like celebrating the poor creatures long life of service rather its extended ordeal of slavery and suffering for a life lived in chains. On a more practical and safety point - a major roof at the site was undergoing roof repairs which involved removing and dumping hundreds if not thousands of clay tiles. column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Kandy, a UNESCO World Heritage site, stands as the last capital of Sri Lanka's ancient kings. Nestled within its verdant hills is the revered Temple of the Tooth, which cradles the Buddha's sacred relic. This relic, symbolizing the living Buddha, has been a spiritual beacon for Buddhists for centuries. Historically, the tooth relic's possession signified governance, with kings seeking its blessings for prosperity and protection. The temple's grandeur reflects diverse architectural influences, from traditional Kandyan designs to intricate Indo-Aryan motifs. Each year, the temple's cultural vibrancy shines during the Esala Perahera, a grand procession drawing thousands with its displays of traditional arts and music. Many Buddhists globally journey to this sanctuary, immersing themselves in Sri Lanka's rich history, art, and traditions. The temple offers glimpses of traditional Kandyan performances, evoking a profound spiritual experience. Its architectural beauty, from the golden roof to delicate carvings, mesmerizes visitors. Beyond its tangible marvels, the Temple of the Tooth epitomizes values of peace, unity, and reverence, standing as a testament to Sri Lanka's historical legacy. To ensure a respectful visit, visitors are advised to observe Puja times at 5.45am 6:30am 10:30am and 6:30pm dress modestly with shoulders and knees covered, preferably in white, and remove shoes upon entering."

column11: Considered as a sacred temple complex containing the sacred tooth relic of Lord Buddha, Shri Dalada Maligawa also known as Palace of sacred tooth. This temple is a must visit for every Buddhist. The tooth relic was originally housed in a rock carved temple in Anuradha pura before it was moved to the present palace / temple at Kandy about five hundred years ago. This centuries old temple is serene and the worshippers pray in silence. The temple was originally built as a royal residential palace by the royal family of Sri Lanka long time ago. The remarkable features of this temple is the renowned recital of Kandy drums is a joy to hear. The musical performance is unique for Sri Lanka.The musical instruments are two drums and a pipe instrument. The performance lasting about half an hour is precisely choreographed. The puja timings are fixed  lasting about half an hour three times in a day - morning, noon and evening. The temple premises are very well secured and spotless maintenance is visible everywhere. You need to be properly dressed to enter the temple. Ensure that your shoulder and knees are covered. The temple management treats every body equal. No preference seems to be given for any one. There is no shouting at or pushing of the pilgrims in the sanctum sanctorium. Everything is done in dignified silence. The temple is a must visit while you are in Kandy, Sri Lanka. Highly recommended.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: One of the best places I have visited during last year and it was so calm and quite place to stay for 2 3 hours. During evening time there are lots of tourists are there and locals too. You have to dress in white and cover all over your body because of sacred thing of the place.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: The Sacred Temple of Tooth is the most iconic place in Sri Lanka. It houses the sacred tooth relic of Lord Buddha and it is the holiest place of Buddhists. inside of the temple is exceptionally beautiful with ancient paintings and wood carvings.  The temple grounds spread out to many hectares and have several important spots under one head. The temple itself is located inside the ancient royal palace complex, which encompasses several devalas, and museums. International Buddhist Museum, Audience hall, meditation grounds, the Rajah Tusker Hall, and many more sights are the reasons for its ingenuity and grandeur. The spiritual power and awesome scenic beauty that surrounds this sacred temple will surely enchant you.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: It's a nice temple and one of the main attractions in Kandy. The walk around the nearby lake is pretty nice too.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We had this amazing temple tour which we loved the most. Before you enter you have to cover your whole body and it would be better if you use white cloths. Inside you will find spiritual calmfulness. They will charge around less than $10 to enter the temple but its really worth the money you spend. You can find a guide who will teach you history of the temple.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We attended the 5:30am (and least crowded) ceremony at the Temple of the Tooth.  The impressive temple complex houses the single most important relic in the Buddhist faith, the tooth of the Buddha, and devotees turn up in great numbers with offerings and prayers as the casket containing the tooth is briefly displayed.  It was a real privilege to witness this special moment (although you don‚Äôt actually get to see the tooth) and later explore the riches the temple complex has to offer.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: One needs to go here early since many people queuing to give offerings to Buddha. There were very few tourists, but then, the country does not have that many tourists. Entrance includes some other museums, including the World Museum of Buddhism. Even if you are not religious, this is very informative. Highly recommend it.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: A place to visit to any person in the world.. Has beautiful paintings and unbelievable architecture.. Gauthama Buddhas tooth of relic is been kept here.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We visited the temple as part of our tour of Sri Lanka and it is certainly not to be missed! Our driver took us around and it was great to have a guide with us to tell us about the history. It was very busy around midday (and very hot!) but absolutely worth the visit. It's a much larger area than we first thought so take the time to look around and visit the museum there too. Shoulders and knees must be covered, photos allowed in most areas (but don't turn your back for a selfie!).

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Very grand temple, different fees for locals and tourists, you can pay at the machine - ideally take the correct amount of change. The inside architecture and decor is impressive and the story of the ancient tooth relic is written on the walls. You can also light lamps outside in prayer or for blessings. I imagine it can be very peaceful. If you don't like crowds don't go at prayer time as it is really busy.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We visited Temple of the Tooth in the evening and watched the Puja Ceremony. There are 3 ceremonies every day 6am, 10am and 6pm. Both men and women must have their shoulders and knees covered. During the ceremony drummers fill the air with rhythmic beats and  prayers.  People line up for the chance to catch a glimpse of the golden case with the tooth inside and offerings of flowers are laid before the sacred tooth‚Äôs chamber. It was very interesting to go at this time of the day and it had a real ambiance about it

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Visiting Kandy is incomplete without visiting temple of Sacred Tooth Relic. The place is heaven for those who have interest in History.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Visited on 18 February 2020 at 10.30am Dress decently. Very important is to wear cloths which cover the body and legs. No shorts or sleeveless tops allowed. For hot days carry cap/scarves. Please note. On Kandy sightseeing, this was the first stopover of the day. The entry tickets were arranged as part of the package which included a CD and souvenir. The location of this temple is beside a lake and approach road has many colonial buildings. The temple complex has many attraction within. Museum, floors, different portions dedicated to rituals and related things. Photos are allowed but not selfies. Respect the rules. This attraction will have long walks so suggest take a guide along and senior citizens must take rest breaks. There is a souvenir shop inside the Museum complex selling authentic Sri Lankan craft at appropriate prices. Authenticity is guaranteed.  Do use this opportunity to take few products back to your country. I bought Elephants (SLR 350), key rings (SLR 80) and fridge magnets  (SLR 200). Beautiful flower shops will amaze you when you exit the temple. You will feel a calmness and happy after visiting this place. Go and enjoy .

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Very interesting place to visit. Thoroughly enjoyed an afternoon there . Helped having a guide to tell you all the facts. Lots of security evident due to previous terror attacks

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We joined the queues during morning prayer. There are two queues to get in: one for the men and one for the women. Like most things in life, the men's line moved faster. This is mainly due to two things: 1) most women carry bags that need searching (most men don't) 2) the women perhaps face a little more scrutiny over what they can wear and must cover-up. Shoulders and legs need to be covered, so make sure you have a light scarf and sarong. Men too should carry a sarong to put on although some western males it seemed were managing to get through in shorts. Once inside make sure you follow the tourist crowds to the right and enter the temple through the tourist entry. Here you leave your shoes, you will be expected to tip after collection. Inside, at prayer, this place is busy. At times you are moved along with the crowd. The locals are of course queuing to leave gifts and to pray so don't feel too bad if you 'skip' queues and glide past those locals waiting on the stairs. The relic itself can't be seen. Instead, you can peer into the golden shrine where it is stored, but at this point in the temple, the crowds are at their busiest so you main only manage a cursory glance. The best part about the temple is exploring the grounds and additional rooms and buildings. The carvings and sculptures of Budha are beautiful, and in most spaces, you can take photos. Just be mindful of people worshipping and not to take pictures with your back to any Budha statue. The grounds of the temple are beautiful, and there is an elephant on the site too, which is used in ceremonies. Although, it is clearly an old elephant and seeing it so heavily chained doesn't make for the best view. At night time, around the temple and Lake, there is a cacophony of noise as bats and birds come to roost in their hundreds. It is the most spectacular site in Kandy and a must-see. The museum of World Buddhism, which is on the site is also worth a visit, and with a tourist ticket to the temple, you have access.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: To enter this place involved some major security & some strange interpretations of covered & uncovered ?? The wife finally got in and we enjoyed the Temple. The actual relic is behind locked & closed doors and only brought out on special occasions. On the floor where the relic is housed the faithful sit down & pray , after leaving floral tributes. The whole thing is quiet & peaceful and the vibe is pleasant. The building & other statues are well worth a look.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

Ladies need to cover their shoulders and everyone must take shoes off - take socks with you as some of the pavements get very hot! column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: This is an excellent temple complex that is locate on the lake side. It will take you half a day to visit the whole site so plan accordingly. A point to bear in mind is the fact that the tooth relic will be on view at certain times of the day so make sure that you time your visit with this. The initial ceremony is on the ground floor but the exposition is on the first floor so don't miss that. It will be busy!

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

Everyone had their palms sprayed with sanitizer due to Covid 19. Mo shorts and singlets allowed but you can wrap a sarong around your legs.  Intense energy with the loud beatings of drums and gongs, trumpets blaring and chanting. Worth visiting for the experience.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Always wanted to visit here as a highly regarded religious site. Had to wear a sarong as we tuned up in shorts. Immediately when we went in a male latched on to us to give us a guided tour. Although he gave much detail he was a bit irritating and hard to shake off. To be fair he showed us everything we wanted to see eg the temple of the tooth and other things in other temples including a stuffed elephant we wouldn't have known about. Temple was being cleaned when we visited so you ended up with very wet feet. I asked why flowers were such a big thing and was told that the Buddha didn't want material things like money or gold so flowers were preferred. I was slightly bemused when on leaving the temple he asked for money. When I offered money I was told it wasn't enough. We eventually settled on 1000 rupees. The person holding the shoes also wanted money so the lack of materialism inside didn't stretch to the staff. Glad I went and would recommend if you have an interest in this sort of thing.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

Also we had to take our shoes off which we have no problem with but weren't warned of the heat of the outdoor floor tiles that we had to walk on and scorched our feet.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: This is another UNESCO World Heritage Site with interesting history and background. The site is located in city centre of Kandy right in front of Kandy Lake. Tooth Relic is believed to be sacred for Buddhism and the royal family was responsible for the safekeeping of the tooth relic. It is believed to be brought from Anuradhapura to Kandy Kingdom. Two storeys building was constructed for safekeeping the tooth relic. But the building was destroyed several times. Each time it was restored whenever it was destroyed. There will be ceremony everyday for the blessings by the devotees. We visited around late afternoon and waited for the ceremony around 6pm plus. Interesting cultural sights, but be prepared for uncontrollable crowds and haphazard situation during the ceremony. The tooth relic is said to be kept within a gold plated ornament, hence it cannot be seen by anyone even during the ceremony. The international Buddhism Museum within the compound is worth to check out too for the interesting architecture and interior design. Overall, it is still worth the entrance fee of LKR1,500 per person and appropriate attire is required and tight security check at the entrance.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We are a couple in early 30s with 9 and 10yr old daughters. Firstly we hadn't dressed appropriately so had to rent sarongs to cover up. The guy was nice enough but still 400rs down. It's a bit of a faff to get in, we went through one lot if security then you get your bag checked again before you go in. We had a tip off from the sarong guy that they take away your cigarettes and lighters so I hid them well in the bag. You have to put your shoes in a shoe storage area. Other reviews are correct about them asking for a donation, I was aware of this and just played deaf when they asked me, I had to assist my child... Oh and don't think you can put your shoes in your bag - that's not allowed! The ticket machines don't give change so you do have to have the right amount on you. There was an attendant who said we didn't have to pay for the children which was good and we didn't have the right change but he helped a guy behind us which then gave us the right change. So that was kind. First off you walk on boiling hot pavement in bear feet. Then I guess the rest is interesting if you like architecture and religious history. As atheists we were a little bemused by all of it. There's nothing to tell you where the tooth is. We assumed we were in the right place by the people praying on the floor... But there's no signs etc and we didn't have a guide. There's a museum which was a little interesting. The saddest part is the taxidermied elephant. Poor thing was captured and kept for a good 50years before he died. He's now stuffed in a glass cabinet. There's a photo timeline of his life since capture but it doesn't have any translation so we don't really know the story... If you like this sort if thing and are in Kandy then maybe pay it a visit... But I definitely wouldn't drive to Kandy for a day trip just for that. In my husbands words "I wouldn't go again even if it was outside my front door".

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Our driver/guide took us to the 6:30pm pooja ceremony which was the perfect timing as it was very atmospheric, with the light fading and the temple coming alive with the ceremony. I would recommend having a guide to explain what is happening and to also guide you through the temple - it was very busy and could feel a bit chaotic if you don‚Äôt have someone with you to guide you through it, and to also take you to all the different rooms. There is a dress code where you need to cover your shoulders and knees, and you also need to take off your shoes.  Security is tight due to a bombing outside the temple a few years ago so give yourself time to get in to the temple. This is a must do when visiting Kandy.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: A bit of a hike from the nearest parking on a hot day. Shoes have to be left at a kiosk outside the temple and there is a dress code. No shoulders or knees allowed to be on show. There is a queue to see the tooth relic and you are not allowed time to admire it but ushered past quickly by security. We had a good guide otherwise wouldn‚Äôt have a clue what it was all about.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We visited the Temple with our guide - the best way to have the inside knowledge. We went to see the offerings at 9.30am, at this time some separate rooms are opened which aren‚Äôt usually open during other hours. FYI you can‚Äôt actually see the tooth; it is well protected in a stupa which is behind a closed door but open during the offering time. It was quite busy but use your manners and getting around is fine. As it is a sacred place, clothing is more strict. Leggings for women need to be covered appropriately and men preferably trousers however my husband just wore a sarong over shorts. Shoulders are also covered accordingly. Make sure you take time to see the ancient paintings portraying the story of the relic and see the taxidermy elephant!

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Spectacular temple with locals using it actively for worship. So much to see and what there is is beautiful. A must visit while in Kandy

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We were staying close to Kandy and knew that this was one of the biggest attractions in the area and our only available day to go was on a Saturday. We left early and got to the temple area around 9:30am. You must leave your shoes with a shoe keeper and buy your ticket in the same area. Make sure you are properly dressed as they will not let you in with any knee or shoulder showing (although you can buy a sarong right there if necessary). Women and men go through separate security lines and for us, the lines were extremely long and quite slow-I believe this was because of our timing. From there, you can make your way into the main temple and line up in a hectic, crowded, and sweaty manner for a VERY quick look at the golden casket which holds the sacred tooth of Buddha. From there, you are free to wander the grounds and look into the different buildings, including a museum with artifacts under glass, a room devoted to the famous temple elephant Raja the Tusker, and also some archeological artifacts. Altogether a very fascinating look into the passionate devotion to Buddha in Sri Lanka.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: We visited this temple as part of an organised tour with Walkers tours and definitely benefited from having our guide, Sumith, giving his insight and sharing his expertise whilst we were there.  I don't think the experience would have been the same without this personal insight and informed commentary. Firstly, to be clear you do not see the sacred tooth! If you are lucky you may get a quick peek at the casket (with its separate 5 locks) where it is housed.  If you are a tourist you can reach this by one very quick queue where Buddhists who wish to leave an offering may queue for 3 hours to reach the relic.  The feeling of reference and respect is overwhelming and moving, just close your eyes for a moment and take in the sounds of chanting and drumming, the smells of essence and offerings, the emotions shown by people of faith.  I can honestly say I felt completely overcome and still shiver at the memory. On leaving this area there is plenty more to see which are less crowded and easier to view.  We particularly enjoyed the room with the pictures outlining the history of the sacred tooth around a statue of Buddha with another place for offerings a must do place in Kandy, particularly if you can have an insight as to why it is so important to the people of Sri Lanka

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

Don't fall for this if he tries to do the same to you!

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic is a Buddhist temple in the city of Kandy, Sri Lanka. It is located in the royal palace complex of the former Kingdom of Kandy.  It is a very important Sri Lankan temple as it houses the relic of the tooth of the Buddha. We visited this temple as part of a G Adventures tour in the evening when the doors of the area where the casket that houses the tooth relic is open,  This allows the locals as well as the tourists to see this casket. Due to problems with possible terrorists, there are high security measures taken before you can enter the temple.  You must also be appropriately dressed with women wearing clothes that cover their shoulders and knees and men should wear full length pants.  Most of the locals wear complete white outfits to show their respect when visiting the temple. It is a very busy in this temple and you cannot wear your shoes in it.  I had a guide help me through the temple, which I would not have been able to do if he had not helped me up and down the numerous stairs you need to use to see the entire temple. The museum that is attached to the temple was also interesting to see as it held many sacred texts about Buddha's life.

column2: Temple of the Sacred Tooth Relic
column11: Religious site with a Buddha tooth relic with a newer building built over the original relic casket. Been told that at twice a day the casket door will be opened for special prayers. The tooth relic was brought over by the King and Queen, and she hid the relic in her hair, when the capital was moved to Kandy. Every year in August, the Festival of the Tooth is one of the grandest festivals in Sri Lanka and in the Buddhist world. It is held every summer in Kandy to honor the sacred tooth of Lord Buddha and to pay homage to old gods of Sri Lanka. For the people of Sri Lanka, it is a time to celebrate the country's rich culture and history
